posts.content:
2025 Post #5

Congratulations to Merrill P. Thomas Co., Inc. for winning the Mobile Chamber's prestigious 2024 Small Business of the Year Award. With over 1700 businesses represented in the, this is not just an honor but should be seen as a phenomenal recognition of the work thatand his team have done not just in the past year but over many decades in the Mobile, Alabama region.

Well deserved. Keep up the good work.

For the other 10 finalists on yesterday, what an amazing honor, and keep up the good work. See you on stage soon, and fingers crossed for your success.

comments.commentText: Thank you and your family for the sponsorship of the award, and for your leadership in our community. The outpouring of support and phenomenal recognition has been overwhelming!
Backend, when you don’t have clear requirements before starting.

posts.name:
Richard King
Richard King
posts.content:
I know I have mentioned this before…but one of the best things about helping people with their resumes…I get to stay in touch with them. 

As my tween son once said, “your friend was once a stranger…”

My heart soars when I get DMs like this. Keep ‘em coming!! Let’s do this together!! I’m here and I’m cheering for you!!!  Rah rah rah!!!

comments.commentText:
It's the best feeling, isn't it? The other day I had an appointment with a job seeker who I've been in touch with since last year. I was excited to see her name on my calendar, because she's wonderful, but disappointed that she's still on the job search. 

Turns out she made the appointment just to tell me that she got a job! It was such a great conversation.

Congratulations to your job seeker friend too!
It depends how you set it up

posts.content:
The Iconic 1965 Shelby Cobra Backdraft: A Timeless Legend! 

This is the 1965 Shelby Cobra Backdraft, a masterpiece that blends classic style with modern engineering to deliver unmatched performance.

 𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗜𝘁 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗻𝗱𝘀 𝗢𝘂𝘁:
Timeless Style: Captivating curves and a design that’s iconic for generations.
Modern Engineering: A roaring engine and advanced mechanics for exhilarating speed and precision.
Legendary Legacy: Owning the Shelby Cobra is owning a piece of history—it’s about the thrill and pride of the open road.

 𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗗𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗥𝗶𝗱𝗲? 
What car would you love to take for a spin? Let’s celebrate the beauty of classic cars in the comments! 

 Follow me for more inspiring stories and legendary moments like this!

comments.commentText: The 1965 Shelby Cobra Backdraft truly embodies the perfect marriage of classic elegance and innovative engineering. It's inspiring to see such a legendary piece of automotive history celebrated here. Thank you for sharing!
Hard to choose only one Jerry Rassamni I love those classics

posts.name:
Alex Brogan
Alex Brogan
posts.content:
80,000 hours is the world's leading authority on impactful careers.

Here's all the evidence-based advice they've found on how to be more successful in any job:

1. Take care of yourself: Prioritize sleep, exercise, diet, and close relationships to significantly enhance happiness, health, and energy levels.
2. Prioritize mental health if needed: Address mental health issues as a top priority; it's essential for your wellbeing and ability to help others.
3. Set goals: Get in the habit of setting goals for personal development. People who set goals tend to achieve more.
4. Become more productive: Apply productivity techniques; small habits greatly enhance your effectiveness and output.
5. Improve basic social skills: Develop foundational social skills; small habits significantly enhance relationships and connections.
6. Apply happiness research: Utilize scientifically-backed techniques to boost wellbeing, happiness, and productivity.
7. Save more money: Build financial security with smart saving habits for flexibility and risk-taking.
8. Learn how to learn: Cultivate meta-learning skills to acquire knowledge quickly, aiding in mastering any field effectively.
9. Deal with physical health, especially back pain: Address physical health issues proactively, with special attention to back pain. It's a major cause of lost productivity.
10. Surround yourself with great people: Build connections; your network influences your opportunities and growth.
11. Perform better in your job: Identify and focus on what's most important for success in your role. Excelling brings many benefits.
12. Improve decision-making: Learn techniques for clearer thinking and better choices. Good decisions compound over time.
13. Work on becoming a better person: Use current media references to connect with fresh ideas effectively.
14. Master a field and make creative contributions: Become an expert gradually for grater impact and satisfaction.
15. Develop useful work skills: Acquire in-demand professional abilities. Focus on skills with good personal fit and future value.

Source:

What would you add?

comments.commentText: Great list Alex Brogan. One addition I’d suggest: Embrace failure as a learning tool. Every setback holds valuable insights that can fuel growth, sharpen skills, and push us closer to mastery.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

posts.name:
Hudson Hector
Hudson Hector
posts.content:
Let’s talk about doubt.

It’s sneaky. It doesn’t scream ‘STOP!’—it whispers just enough to make you hesitate.

- ‘What if I’m not good enough?’
- ‘What if I fail?’
- ‘What if everyone finds out I don’t have what it takes?’
Sound familiar?

The truth is, doubt kills more dreams than failure ever will because it stops you before you even begin.

But here’s the thing: Doubt isn’t a sign that you’re not capable. It’s a sign that you’re stepping outside your comfort zone—and that’s where real growth happens.

 Imagine what your life could look like if you acted despite the doubt.

What if you told that little voice, ‘I hear you, but I’m doing this anyway’?

Here’s your challenge today: Take one small step toward your dream—even if doubt is whispering in your ear.

Prove to yourself that fear doesn’t control you.

Drop a  in the comments if you’re ready to quiet the doubt and take action. Because the world doesn’t need perfection—it needs you to show up.

posts.name:
Richard King
Richard King
posts.content:
Why I will never stop berating job seekers about their dreadful resumes and charging $30 for a resume and LinkedIn profile review call: if you honestly, hand over your heart, don’t think my feedback is constructive/helpful…don’t pay me. Ha! I don’t care!

I berate because I care!! (Hey…that would look great on a bumper sticker)

I charge $30 because I value my time. I value my family. I value my 15 years of experience and I value my 100,000+ resume reads.

Also, the $30 allows me to help dozens of job seekers every month…for FREE! Those that are truly in dire straits. And I have a soft spot for fellow Recruiters who have hit 9+ months.

Nothing would make me happier than knowing each and every job seeker in America has a fantastic resume aka a marketing document.

Until then…

!!!

comments.commentText: Charging also means people take it seriously. I ran a hypnosis business as a side hustle for years. I have the data to back it up that when someone paid me $75 for an initial session and $35 for a back up, the results were great whether it was for weight loss, quit smoking, dealing with phobias, etc. The few times I did them for free to help someone who was in a jam, there were few positive results. They had no skin in the game and so had no reason to want it to work.
Russell Irby You make a good point. Sadly, more times than not…when I offer to do a free review…the person is a no-show for the appointment

As someone who paid for your services, the insight you gave me for $30 was incredible. 

Anyone who complains about the $30, my question is: Are you paying for more than ONE subscription service? (Netflix, Hulu, etc) - what's more important, binging a series or a resume that'll land you your next job?

Deidre Henry Yes! I’ve oftern compared it to a few fancy coffees at Starbucks. 

Sometime I’m speaking so quickly….we get the call done in 11 minutes. 

“22 dollars? That’s all you want?” “Yup!”

posts.name:
Dr. Josh Ramirez, NPPQ, PMP
Dr. Josh Ramirez, NPPQ, PMP
posts.content:
I’ve spent quite a bit of time with a lot of different AI models and the one thing I’ve learned is that, from a human thinking and behavior standpoint, AI has got a super long way to go.

We thought AI was ‘almost there,’ in terms of intelligence. It’s not.

There’s a lot of training left to do! And it won’t happen overnight.

comments.commentText:
Here is my understanding of the limitations of large language models compared to human thinking, particularly in their architecture and processing capabilities. Would you agree?
Model Architecture
Large language models, such as GPT, have a fixed context window limiting how much text they can process at once. Current models support up to 100,000 tokens (roughly 75,000 words or fewer).
This limitation stems from the Transformer architecture, which requires maintaining attention across all tokens. As the token count increases, the computational load grows exponentially.
Performance and Practicality
Processing larger texts in a single pass requires significantly more memory and computational power, leading to slower response times and higher costs.
Many documents can be effectively analyzed by breaking them into smaller sections for summary and analysis, which reduces the need for extensive context windows.
Cost and Efficiency
Expanding context windows demands additional resources, increasing operational costs for providers and users alike.
